text: I think you put the bottoms wrong and that's why you can't use the whole table area. Look carefully. These lower two aluminum plates, on one is attached the motor, on the other the handle for rotation. They have to be turned upside down, the protruding things on these aluminum plates are actually the legs of the machine and they have to be down. If you turn these parts upside down, the table will be able to pass over them and have more space for movement.
video: What can a $300 CNC do? - Ortur Aufero CNC Engrave

text:
I custom built ours for our small business, but I also have an engineering background and several years experience with 3d printers and motion systems including modifying firmware..  It is a 7W diode that I will be upgrading to 10W soon on a approximately 5 ft x 5 ft frame (about 1400mm squared actual work space).  My other half and sister in law do a lot of sewn products for people, and being able to laser cut when you need 50 of the same pattern cut at a time is a huge timesaver.  It cost me around $1000 in parts to build plus a lot of time, but even a diode unit that large would be a few thousand dollars minimum.  I could have dropped that price by 3d printing more parts instead of using aluminum for 99% of the machine.

I recognize that is not a good option for most people though.
video: The Best Laser Cutter for any Budget?

text:
I think the changes are a big negative for hobby users or those teaching themselves or in the pre-start-up phase.

They made 3 axis projects take a lot longer by removing rapids. A 3-hour project will now take 12 hours which is huge if you have to stand watching the machine (as most hobby users do). Not to mention the extra power usage...

They made 4 and 5 axis hobby cnc machines useless by removing that functionality completely. This limits what you can make regardless if it's a one-off hobby job or full production. 

Manual tool changes have been made needlessly arduous as they now require a whole new operation.

They could have achieved the stated goal by simply limiting the hobby version to only posting to Mach 3 and Linuxcnc which no commercial VMCs use. 

Most of what they removed has nothing to do with commercial operations. It looks more aimed at forcing hobby users to pay for expensive subscriptions for the small handful of personal projects they do.

text:
I really enjoy your channel, but a factor none of the review channels seem to discuss is the VERY short service life for xTool products. As recently as 9 months ago, xTool was heavily promoting their D1 and D1 Pro lasers, yet if one visits their site now, ALL of the replacement parts are "out of stock", and none of the laser heads can be replaced, with the exception of the $1,200 40w head for the D1 Pro.

So if your machine breaks, be aware you cannot get parts to repair it. This seems to be true for all xTool products, and I think a 2 year (maximum) service life is preposterous for a tool at this price-point.
video: The ALMOST perfect laser: The xTool S1 Laser Revie

text: In these videos on different machines you barely show the actual results of any engraving. No comparisons to other machines output, no closeups, dim and blurry shots, no common objects like a pencil or ruler next to the engraving for scale, no side by side comparisons to commercial products with engraving, no comparisons to the same engraving printed with a office laser printer. The manufacturers web sites also don't generally show anything with any detail. I can only conclude these non-industrial laser engraving machines in general don't do a good job. I think anybody shopping for any laser engraver should see results in person with the products they want to engrave.

text: I like the idea of getting a laser cutter/engraver, but I am wholly against getting one without a full enclosure that's fully opaque to the laser frequency the machine uses. Sure you can wear goggles and protect yourself, but if there's any more than zero chance that someone else could walk in while it's running, no matter how small, then I'm unwilling to accept the risk of inadvertently causing permanent eye damage to them. Class 4 lasers are nothing to play with; even just seeing the spot they make can cause eye damage before the signal reaches the brain.
video: Laser Companies are Lying to You

Exacly how compatible is the Polar with Lightburn?  Are you able to use ALL of the Polar's features with Lightburn, or only some of the features?  Such as the camera, auto focus etc?  
Asking because I just got the Xtool P2 that claims to be compatible with Lightburn, and yes, it sort of is, however its VERY limited. Cant use cameras, no auto focus and I have to manually put in stats of my cut material each time.  It sucks.  Pretty much have to use the Xtool software which is nowhere near as good as Lightburn!  I'm considering getting the Polar instead.
